abstract.text: A view controller that delivers input either from the responder chain to views, or from game controllers to profiles.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: On systems, such as tvOS, where the player uses the game controller to both navigate the system interface and play your game, use a

object as the root view controller to selectively receive input directly from the game controller. You can’t simultaneously process input through the responder chain and Game Controller input elements.
By default the system delivers input events to your app using the responder chain. To get the input values through the game controller objects, set a

object as the root view controller. The view controller delivers the input for its views and their subviews to the game controller’s profile. To switch back to the responder chain, set the view controller’s

abstract.text: A true value.
Support hardware game controllers in your game.
A view controller that delivers input either from the responder chain to views, or from game controllers to profiles.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the system delivers game controller input to profile objects or to views using the responder chain.
Use touch input and virtual controllers to make your game available to players without controllers.

doc://com.apple.gamecontroller/documenta.title: Adding touch controls to games that support game controllers in iOS

abstract.text: A controller that manages a view, typically loaded from a nib file.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A set of methods that support the mediation of a custom segue.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
